questions.text: A 52-year-old patient, case of BT Hansen presented to the OPD with the following condition. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The trophic ulcer is one of the leprosy sequelae due to peripheral neuropathy

  • The pathogenesis is mainly related to the abnormally increased pressure in areas such as the sole, secondary to the lack of sensation, and deformities induced by peripheral sensory-motor neuropathy
  • Trophic ulcers can cause economic and social burdens, and may influence the patient's quality of life
  • Trophic ulcer in leprosy patients can pose a significant stigma to the patients and remain challenging to clinicians due to the low response to treatment.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

questions.text: Slit skin smear can be used in the diagnosis of :
questions.solution:
Slit skin smear:

  • Leprosy- shows acid fast bacilli.

Bacteriological and morphological indices can be calculated.

  • Leishmaniasis-

Used to demonstrate LD bodies

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 3

choices.text: Lepra reaction are divided into three phases
Early reaction is also called as mitsuda reaction
Mitsuda reaction is seen with 3 to 4 months
Presence of erythema and edema is considered to be positive early reaction

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Lepra reactions:

  • Early [fernandes]:
  • Early reaction occurs within 48 hours
  • Edema and erythema more than 5mm are considered as positive
  • Late [mitsuda]:
  • Develops later 3 to 4 weeks
  • Development of nodule, often ulceration and necrosis is seen.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 3

questions.text: A patient of pure neuritic Hansen disease is sent to you for nerve biopsy. Which nerve biopsy will be suitable for biopsy?
questions.solution:
Sural nerve will be suitable for biopsy for a patient of pure neuritic Hansen disease.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

questions.text: Most commonly seen leprosy after dapsone monotherapy:
questions.solution:
• Histoid leprosy is a distinct and rare variant of lepromatous leprosy, and it was described by Wade1 in 1963.
  • It is characterized by unique clinical, histopathological, and microbiological features.
  • This form of leprosy is fairly common in patients on dapsone monotherapy and irregular treatment.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

questions.text: Known patient or leprosy. Which nerve is thickened?
questions.solution:
The GAN is a large sensory nerve in the posterior triangle of the neck, traversing upward and parallel to the external jugular vein. It is the commonest pure sensory cutaneous nerve affected in leprosy.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

questions.text: You're providing an in-service on skin cancer prevention to a local group of parents and grandparents. One topic you discuss is the identification of melanoma. Select all the characteristics of this type of skin cancer you will educate the participants about:
questions.solution:
When educating about how to identify melanoma using the ABCDE acronym.

A: asymmetrical,

B: borders uneven (dissimilar),

C: color dark or multiple colors,

D: diameter greater than 6 mm (NOT 8 mm).

E: evolution (lesion increases in size, shape, color)

questions.text: A 44-year-old male security guard presents with skin changes and mild right upper quadrant discomfort. He returned home abruptly from vacation due to his symptoms. His medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, and he admits to consuming large quantities while sunbathing on the beach. Physical examination demonstrates skin hyperpigmentation and a mixture of tense vesicles and erosions bilaterally over the dorsal surfaces of both hands and both feet. Additionally, there is skin hyperpigmentation of the face, posterior neck, and chest. He reports that a similar episode occurred approximately three years ago after helping his brother build a shed in Arizona. What amino acid is required for the rate-limiting step of the synthetic pathway that is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria.
  • It occurs due to the defective function of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen III decarboxylase.
  • PCT can be acquired or inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.
  • The acquired type tends to occur in middle-aged or older men with a history of cirrhosis or chronic alcohol use disorder.
  • The heme pathway starts with the synthesis of D-aminolaevulinic acid from succinyl-CoA and glycine.
  • Succinyl-CoA is derived from the Krebs cycle.
  • Clinical features of the condition include photosensitivity resulting in hyperpigmentation, scarring, blistering of sun-exposed skin (as seen in this patient), hypertrichosis, and tea-colored urine.

questions.text: A patient with history of herpes simplex virus infection presented with fever, arthralgia and uneasiness which is accompanied by skin lesion on palm and back of hands and feet. What is the likely clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• Erythema multiforme is an inflammatory reaction, characterized by target or iris skin lesions.
  • Oral mucosa may be involved. Diagnosis is clinical. Lesions spontaneously resolve but frequently recur.
  • Erythema multiforme usually occurs as a reaction to an infectious agent such as herpes simplex virus or mycoplasma but may be a reaction to a drug.
  • Suppressive antiviral therapy may be indicated for patients with frequent or symptomatic recurrence due to herpes simplex virus

choices.text: Symmetrical drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthema

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus presents with erythema of the lower leg. The diagnosis of cellulitis was confirmed, and amoxicillin treatment was started. He developed seven days after amoxicillin intake symmetrical areas of sharply demarcated erythema in the anogenital region and axillary folds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Symmetrical drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthema (SDRIFE) is characterized by a symmetrical erythematous rash on the gluteal and intertriginous areas which is observed after exposure to systemic drugs.
  • In contrast to baboon syndrome, there is no history of contact dermatitis.
  • Culprit drugs are most commonly amoxicillin or another beta-lactam antibiotic.
  • A history of chemotherapy administration 2 to 4 weeks earlier helps distinguish between symmetrical drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthema and toxic erythema of chemotherapy.

choices.text: Brain and Testis involvement is rare
Commonly presents with crusting and scaling on trunk, calvaria defects and floating teeth
Treatment of refractory histiocytosis is cladribine

questions.text: The following statement is false about Langerhans cell histiocytosis:
questions.solution:
• Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • IHC marker:
  • CD1a
  • S100
  • CD 207

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 142

questions.text: You are a dermatology resident. You have a histopathology discussion, where you see a fungal hypha sandwiched between the layer of stratum corneum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sandwich sign: Histopathological sign of dermatophytosis; hyphae 'sandwiched' between upper normal and lower compact orthokeratotic/parakeratotic stratum corneum

Sporotrichosis and mucromycosis are deeper fungal infection.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 3

choices.text: Does not occur with the use of 2% hydroquinone
Occurs due to continual use, not necessarily in higher concentration

questions.text: True about hydroquinone and ochronosis is
questions.solution: Occurs due to continual use, not necessarily in higher concentration about hydroquinone and ochronosis.

questions.text: A 27 year old male presents to STI clinic with the following. He has history of unprotected homosexual intercourse with complaints of burning micturition and pus discharge from the urethra which of the following complications can develop in long run if not treated appropriately?
questions.solution:
Complication of gonorrhoea:

Male :

  • Saxophone penis
  • Acute prostatis
  • Epididymo-orchitis
  • Periurethral abscess

Female:

  • Acute salpingitis
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Bartholin glands abscess
  • Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 30, 9th edition

choices.text: Should be routinely performed in all patients of skin disease
Highly correlated with the disease activity

questions.text: True about Anti-nuclear antibodies test is :
questions.solution:
• The American College of Rheumatology ANA task force in 2009 recommended that the immunofluorescence test should remain the gold standard for ANA testing, due to high sensitivity (>95%).
  • When to test for ANA. ANA test must be performed only when there is a clinical suspicion of an autoimmune CTD.
  • If screening test for ANA is positive, further tests for specific autoantibodies must be ordered, based on the clinical features and possible diagnosis.
  • If ANA screening is negative, patient must be re-evaluated and kept under follow-up, and test must be repeated only if clinically indicated.

questions.text: A female presents to the clinic with non-itchy gritty black nodules on her scalp hair.. Microscopic examination with 10% KOH revealed nodules on the hair shaft which were made up of closely packed brown hyphae held in a mass by a cement-like substance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Black iedra predominantly affects scalp hairs, characterized by firmly adherent black hard nodules that are gritty on palpation. Although asymptomatic, the fungus grows into the hair shaft causing hair to fracture easily.
  • In a case of black iedra, microscopic examination of nodules with 10% to 20% KOH shows the presence of closely packed brown hyphae held in a mass by a cement-like substance. The center of the nodules reveals many asci containing ascospores with thick hyphal strands at the periphery.
  • Black iedra is a fungal infection of the hair shafts. The appropriate treatment of this condition would involve the application of antifungal agents like 2% ketoconazole

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 32, 9th edition

choices.text: A history of diabetes type 1 since the age of 6 years old
A history of measles 20 days ago
A history of acute leukemia during the past year

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presented with firm neck edema, evolving for 5 days. The diagnosis of scleredema of Buschke is considered. Which of these items would increase the likelihood of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Type 1 scleredema of Buschke is common among children.
  • History should focus on recent history. It usually appears after a viral episode.
  • Scleredema type 1 is the largest group and affects about 55% of the cases.
  • It presents mostly in the pediatric population and young adults.
  • Typically, the onset of scleredema is abrupt and starts after 2 to 3 weeks following a febrile infectious episode, usually streptococcal throat infection and less commonly a viral illness.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 96, 9th edition

choices.text: Inhibitor of the active catalytic site of HIV-1 protease
Inhibitor of the biosynthesis of ergosterol

questions.text: A 9-year-old male with HIV-1 is taking efavirenz, lamivudine, and zidovudine. He presents with his father for follow-up after being treated with a course of topical clotrimazole for tinea cruris. His symptoms have resolved, but he has noticed that he is easily fatigued. His temperature is. Routine blood work is ordered that includes a complete metabolic panel and complete blood count. Results of the laboratory findings are significant for a white blood cell count of 3,400 cells per microL and hemoglobin of 8.2 g/dL. What is the mechanism of action of the medication that is most likely causing this patient's abnormal lab results?
questions.solution:
• Zidovudine is a synthetic analog of the nucleoside thymidine. It is classified as a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). The child most likely has zidovudine-associated neutropenia and anemia.
  • Bone marrow suppression seen with zidovudine includes neutropenia, leukopenia, and anemia.
  • Anemia requiring blood transfusions has been reported to be as high as 19.7% with the use of zidovudine. Anemia and neutropenia usually are reversible when zidovudine is stopped

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 96, 9th edition

questions.text: A 27 year old man develops warts on his hand. Which of the following is a correct statement concerning these skin lesions?
questions.solution:
• Warts are caused by HPV virus.
  • They have no malignant potential.
  • They are contagious.
  • Salactin paint/TCA application is the treatment.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 30, 9th edition

choices.text: It is used in the classification of leprosy
Negative in infants less than 6 months
BCG vaccination may convert negative to positive

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about 'Lepromin test'?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic test for leprosy:

  • Monofilament test
  • Histamine test
  • Prognostic test for leprosy:
  • Lepromin test.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

choices.text: Give rest to the affected limbs

questions.text: A 27 year old male was diagnosed with borderline leprosy and started on MDT. Six weeks later he developed swelling and pain of skin lesion and nerve tenderness. What should not be done in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Current scenario indicate leprosy reaction.

Type 1 - reversal reaction

Type 2 - erythema nodosum leprosum

In both the cases MDT drugs should not be stopped.

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

questions.text: Most common presentation of neuritic form of Hansens is:
questions.solution:
• Mononeuritis multiplex is the most common presentation of Pure neuritic Hansen.
  • More common in India and Nepal
  • Nerve is thickened with pain and tenderness
  • Predominant sensory neuropathy
  • Nerve biopsy is gold standard

Reference: Illustrated synopsis of dermatology, Neena Khanna, chapter 14

choices.text: Discoid erythematous plaques with hyperpigmented border

questions.text: The most common cutaneous presentation of Subacute lupus erythematosus is:
questions.solution:
Subacute lupus erythematosus presents with:

  1. Papulo-squamous lesion - non scarring (most common)
  2. Annular polycyclic plaques

questions.text: Which of the following is appropriate term for the following dermatitis?
questions.solution:
• The above shows 'trickle dermatitis' occurring when perfume is applied and it trickles down over the trunk.
  • The phototoxic ingredient causing the pigmentation proved to be bergapten, a component of oil of bergamot, derived from the rind of C bergamia, the bergamot lime.
  • Several cases were reported in the 1950s and 1960s following increased use of perfumes containing oil of bergamot and the passion for sunbathing. Since the introduction of artificial oil of bergamot and the reduced use of the natural product in perfumes, berloque dermatitis has become rare

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 88, 9th edition

questions.text: All of the following cutaneous infections are caused by staphylococcus aureus except?
questions.solution:
Disease caused by staphylococcus species:

  • Furuncle
  • Carbuncle
  • Folliculitis
  • Bullous impetigo
  • TSS
  • SSSS

Disease caused by streptococcus species:

  • Cellulitis
  • Erysipelas
  • Scarlet fever
  • Ecthyma
  • Erythema nodosum

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 23, 9th edition

choices.text: Intravenous hydration followed by conservative management

questions.text: A one-day-old infant presents with a rash, mostly on the trunk. The infant is feeding well, and his vitals are age-appropriate. He is admitted for observation. Initially, there were papules, but pustules have developed, surrounded by erythematous skin. The rest of the exam is normal. What will you advice?
questions.solution:
• Scattered, erythematous papules & pustules that occur on any part of the body other than the palms and soles, in full-term neonates in the first 2 weeks of life develop in erythema toxicum neonatorum.
  • It is a benign, self-limited, transient, evanescent eruption that occurs in approximately 48% to 72% of full-term infants.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 116.4, 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of Hydroxychloroquine?
questions.solution:
Diseases with dermatologic manifestations that have been effectively treated with hydroxychloroquine therapy

  • Annular elastotic granuloma
  • Lipo-dermato-sclerosis
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Morphea
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica
  • Dermatomyositis Perniosis
  • Eosinophilic annular erythema
  • Polymorphous light eruption
  • Eosinophilic fasciitis
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Follicular mucinosis
  • Reticular erythematous mucinosis
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Granuloma annulare

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 116.4, 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of the image given below is false?
questions.solution:
• Bullous impetigo is due to S. aureus that produces an exfoliative exotoxin, exfoliatin.
  • This cleaves desmoglein 1 complex and produces a split between stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum within the epidermis.
  • Regional lymphadenitis is seen in non-bullous impetigo.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 26, 9th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a bacterial infection of the skin?
questions.solution:
• Ecthyma contagiosum, also known as and ovine pustular dermatitis, is a virus disease of sheep and goats which is occasionally transmitted to man.
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum : non-infectious neutrophilic disease
  • Impetigo herpetiformis: pustular psoriasis

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 26, 9th edition

choices.text: Ballooning degeneration of keratinocyte with eosinophila and cytoplasmic inclusion seen

questions.text: A farmer developed a single papule on his left index finger within a week of handling his goats. The papules enlarges into a haemorrhagic bullae and healed after 3 to 6 weeks. The lesions was diagnosed to be ORF. Identify the incorrect statement.
questions.solution:
• Orf virus is a double-stranded DNA virus.
  • As a poxvirus, Orfviridaeshares the family's rare trait for promiscuous mammalian cell entry.
  • They do not require a specific receptor; instead, they utilize ambiguous and commonplace components such as glycosaminoglycans for attachment and fusion into the host cell.
  • Thus, abrasions and breaks on human skin aid in giving access to the basal keratocyte layer with an increased likelihood of infection.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 26, 9th edition

questions.text: The concentration of sunscreen applied on the skin for SPF determination is
questions.solution:
SPF is defined as the ratio of the dose of UVR (290-400 nm) required to produce 1 minimal erythema dose (MED) on sunscreen-protected skin (after application of 2 mg/cm2 of product) over the dose to produce 1 MED on unprotected skin

Reference: Article: Sunscreens - what's important to know

questions.text: Which investigation is showed in the above image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows nail fold capillaroscopy

  • Done with hand held dermatoscope
  • Performed on proximal nail fold
  • Done in connective tissue disease

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 55, 9th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient on sulfonamide develops a generalized rash with atypical target lesions with severe mucosal lesions. The body surface area is less than 10 percent. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, chapter 55, 9th edition

questions.text: A 27-year-old sexually active male develops a blister on glans soon after taking tab paracetamol for fever. The lesion healed with hyperpigmentation. The most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Fixed pigmented erythema (FPE), also known as a fixed drug eruption, occurs 24 hours to a few days after administration of the offending medication.
  • The classic form is characterized by a single or multiple round to oval-shaped, red to brown macules.
  • These lesions have the potential to evolve into plaques with vesicles or blistering.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 113

questions.text: Which of the following condition shows interface dermatitis?
questions.solution:
• Interface dermatitis refers to:
  • Interface dermatitis includes conditions in which the primary pathology involves the 'interface', i.e., the dermo-epidermal junction. The components of this 'interface' include the basal layer of the epidermis, the dermo-epidermal junction, the papillary dermis, and the adventitial dermis around the adnexal structures

Example:

  • Lichen planus
  • Lichen planus pigmentosus
  • Lichenoid drug eruption
  • Pityrisis lichenoides chronica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Graft vs host disease

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 42

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of plaque psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate is the drug of choice for plaque psoriasis when it is not controlled merely with topical treatment
  • NB UVB phototherapy is preferred
  • Cyclosporine can be used for short term to control the acute flares of Psoriasis
  • However, systemic steroids are contraindicated.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to you with multiple pustular and nodular acne. She has been treated with cap isotretinoin earlier. Patient insists to restart the same treatment. Which of the following adverse events is related to it?
questions.solution:
• As the patient belongs to reproductive age group, it is most important to explain the teratogenic effects of isotretinoin.
  • Isotretinoin should be stopped 1 to 3 months before planning conception.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 90

questions.text: The condition shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Keloid.

  • Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue caused by skin trauma. Unlike hypertrophic scars, keloids grow beyond the boundaries of the original wound.
  • Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) and platelet-derived growth factor are thought to be the primary driving force of keloid development.
  • TGF-beta promotes chemotaxis of fibroblasts to the site of inflammation, causing collagen production.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 90

questions.text: Acneform ERUPTION caused by the occupational exposure of chemicals is called:
questions.solution:
• Acne/acneform eruption caused due to exposure to chemicals.
  • Straw colored cysts, temporal comedones and retroauricular inolement are all important clues to diagnosis of chloracne
  • Due to occupational exposure from Chloracne. Chloraphthalene, chlorophenyl (used as conductors and insulator), and chlorophenols (used as insecticide and fungicide) can cause acneiform eruptions.
  • Lesions are mainly comedones without inflammation.
  • Exposure by inhalation, ingestion, or direct contact of contaminated compounds or foods induces a cutaneous eruption of polymorphous comedones and cysts which is called as chloracne.
  • Associated skin findings include xerosis, and pigmentary changes are also seen. Internal organs like eyes, central nervous system and liver may also be affected. Some chloracnegens can be oncogenic.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 130

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a two-day history of an acute skin eruption. She has been taking 20 mg/day of oral prednisone since she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus two weeks ago. Examination shows monomorphic papules and pustules. The skin eruption is most likely at which location?
questions.solution:
• This patient likely presents with acneiform eruption caused by taking a systemic corticosteroid (prednisone).
  • Steroid acne presents as mono-morphous papulo-pustules located mainly on the trunk and extremities.
  • Topical corticosteroids may cause acneiform eruption over the skin where it is applied, and inhaled steroids may be a cause around the nose or mouth.
  • Other drugs that can induce acneiform eruptions include nystatin, isoniazid, corticotropin, naproxen, and hydroxychloroquine.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 130

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of non-scarring hair loss?
questions.solution: Tufted hair - more than one hair shaft emerge from a single follicular opening as a result of abnormal follicular dynamics related to fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following laser is used for targeted phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Excimer laser

  • Used for targeted phototherapy
  • Wavelength 308nm
  • Used in Vitiligo, palmoplantar psoriasis, alopecia areata

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, chapter 21

choices.text: They are derived from neural crest cells
S100 is a marker of melanocyte
Dark colored skin has a greater number of melanocytes
1 melanocyte supply melanin to 36 keratinocytes

questions.text: Pick up a false statement related to melanocyte:
questions.solution:
Determination of skin color:

  • Activity of melanocyte (larger melanosomes give darker color)
  • Type of melanin (eumelanin imparts brown black color)

Skin color is independent of number of melanocytes.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, chapter 21

choices.text: They are present over the glans penis
They are present on the lips
They are not present on foreskin
They are present on labia minora

questions.text: True about the distribution of eccrine sweat glands:
questions.solution:
• Distribution of eccrine gland:
  • They are present over the whole skin surface,
  • Including glans penis and foreskin
  • They are absent on lips, labia minora and external ear canal

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 94.1

questions.text: A patient developed bullae without erythema on elbows, knee and sacral area followed by crust formation, scarring and milia. He had no photosensitivity and negative family history. On DIF IgG deposition DEJ with no blood vessel involvement is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• EBA is a non-genetic autoimmune disease, caused by the development of antibodies (proteins that typically attack foreign substances) against type VII collagen.
  • An examination of skin blisters will show antibodies deposited in the basement membrane between the epidermis and dermis.
  • This form of EB is quite rare and generally affects adults.
  • DIF will be negative in EB dystrophica as there are no antibodies.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 84.1

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of vaginal discharge for the past 7 days. A vaginal swab is taken, which shows a pH of 4.9. Urinalysis is unremarkable. The discharge is further sent for laboratory investigations. When prepared as a wet mount, clue cells can be observed under the microscope. It gives off a fishy odor when KOH is applied to it. What is this test called?
questions.solution:
• This patient meets three out of four of Amsel's criteria; the presence of clue cells on wet mount, vaginal discharge pH greater 4.5, and positive whiff test.
  • Bacterial vaginosis can be diagnosed in this case as she meets the Amsel criteria. The first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis is metronidazole.

Reference: IADVL textbook of dermatology, 4th edition chapter 4

questions.text: As a resident doctor in dermatology, you are told to transport the skin biopsy sample. What is the most widely used transport media?
questions.solution:
• Specimen for histopathology are sent in formalin.
  • Specimen for direct immunofluorescence are taken in normal saline and processed immediately

Reference: IADVL textbook of dermatology, 4th edition chapter 4

choices.text: 5% permethrin cream applied twice each day for 3 weeks
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours
1% permethrin cream applied once each day for a week
5% permethrin cream applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 5 hours

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents to the clinic due to pruritus. He has no significant past medical history. Physical examination reveals inflammatory papules and burrows between the finger webs and on the buttocks. Which medication should be prescribed, and how should it be administered?
questions.solution:
• This patient's presentation is consistent with scabies.
  • To treat scabies, 5% permethrin cream should be applied from the patient's head to toes and washed off after 8 to 14 hours.
  • Mucosal sites should be avoided when applying topical permethrin.
  • Close contacts of patients with scabies should also be treated.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 33

questions.text: A 32 year old lady present to dermatology OPD with itching over the pubic area at night. On examination, the patient has bluish grey coloured spots in the affected area. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pthirus pubis is the pubic louse that colonises pubic hair, axillary hair, eyebrows and beard
  • Itching at night classic
  • Bluish grey colored spots- maculae cerulae lesion acquire typical color because of hemosiderin deposition secondary to bite marks

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 33

choices.text: Melanin is absent in vellus hair
Vellus hair depth extends to subcutis
The medulla is thicker in terminal hair

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the types of hair.
questions.solution:
Vellus hair depth extends to mid dermis

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 84
